conclusion: To determine if the particle has returned to its starting point at the 3-second mark, we need to analyze the area under the velocity-time (v-t) graph, as this area represents the displacement of the particle.
The velocity-time graph shows how the velocity of the particle changes over time.
The area under the graph from t = 0 to t = 3 seconds will give us the displacement.
From t = 0 to t = 1 second, the velocity is constant at 2 m/s.
From t = 1 to t = 2 seconds, the velocity decreases linearly from 2 m/s to -2 m/s.
From t = 2 to t = 3 seconds, the velocity remains constant at -2 m/s.

premise: From t = 0 to t = 1 second, the velocity is constant at 2 m/s.
conclusion: Area from t = 0 to t = 1 second is a rectangle with height 2 m/s and width 1 second, resulting in an area of 2 m.

premise: From t = 1 to t = 2 seconds, the velocity decreases linearly from 2 m/s to -2 m/s.
conclusion: Area from t = 1 to t = 2 seconds is a triangle with base 1 second and height from 2 m/s to -2 m/s, resulting in an area of 2 m.

premise: From t = 2 to t = 3 seconds, the velocity remains constant at -2 m/s.
conclusion: Area from t = 2 to t = 3 seconds is a rectangle with height -2 m/s and width 1 second, resulting in an area of -2 m.

premise: Areas calculated: 2 m (0 to 1s), 2 m (1 to 2s), -2 m (2 to 3s).
conclusion: Total Displacement = 2 m + 2 m - 2 m = 2 m.
The particle has a total displacement of 2 meters after 3 seconds, which means it has not returned to its starting point. The particle is 2 meters away from the starting point at the 3-second mark.
